docs.lead_paragraph: Peggy Parraga, a part-time massage therapist from Queens, divides her life into two phases: the time when she and her family had health insurance, and now, when they do not. Seven years ago, she had a baby at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx, which accepted her managed care plan, offered good prenatal care and even served her and her husband a celebratory champagne dinner. In 1996, pregnant again but uninsured, she could afford only a clinic at Elmhurst Hospital Center, and endured a chaotic and unpleasant delivery by a doctor she had never met before.

headline.main: No Medical Insurance Means Tough, and Creative, Choices

docs.abstract: Americans who lack medical insurance are devising creative but tough strategies to obtain and pay for medical care; 75 percent of 43 million Americans without health insurance work at least part time but are not offered insurance through employer or cannot afford contribution; individual coverage can be prohibitively expensive or too meager to be worth cost, hence many avoid going to doctors when there is option not to, go without coverage for occasional medical emergencies, borrow medication from relatives or take over-the-counter antidotes; strategies often fail for those with complicated or chronic health problems; emergency rooms provide respite in extreme cases, but their use by uninsured imposes strain on system, which eventually writes off as bad debt costs such patients are unable to pay; photos (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: There he was last week, the German Chancellor, no less, on a television talk show being asked if he would submit to a test that would determine if the color of his abundant dark brown hair was real. Yes, Gerhard Schroder said with a coy grin, ''This is all genuine, really everything.'' It was a moment that captured the extent of Germany's transformation during the four-month rule of the 54-year-old Mr. Schroder. His predecessor, Helmut Kohl, rarely appeared on talk shows, let alone to talk about his (gray) hair. Mr. Schroder, a white-toothed modern image merchant, has popularized the exercise of power.

headline.main: German Leader Is Popular, but Grip Seems Unsure

docs.abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's personal popularity remains high after four months in office but his grip remains unsure; abrupt and unexplained shifts in major policies have raised sharp questions in media, and many Germans grumble that his efforts to popularize exercise of power with glad-handing and informal style may be trivializing governance to point where Europe's most powerful country, though sublimely coiffed at top, may be rudderless; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An eye-catching article in the latest issue of The New England Journal of Medicine has head-and-shoulder portraits of eight ''patients'' wearing hospital gowns staring at the camera. In reality they were actors, four black and four white, who described identical symptoms of chest pain. A videotape of them was later shown to 720 doctors. The ''patients'' were presented in the same settings and given comparable occupations and medical-insurance status. The only differences among them were their race, age and sex. Each doctor was asked to estimate the likelihood that a patient had a narrowing of the coronary arteries and then, based on results of a stress test, to say whether the patient should be referred to a cardiologist for a catheterization. An analysis of the responses confirmed what previous studies have also suggested: women and blacks were 40 percent less likely to be referred for cardiac catheterization than whites and men.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Texas Tech University professor of medicine Abraham Verghese on findings of bias in patient-doctor relationships; says biases should not be surprising, particularly considering bias and complex hierarchies within system that determine where new doctors train (M)
